Authors:
Stanislav Korenko, Tamara Spasojevic, Seraina
Klopfstein
Title:
Wide range of hosts and manipulations of their web-building
behavior in the true spider parasitoid Zatypota kauros (Hymenoptera,
Ichneumonidae)
Journal: Zoological Journal of the Linnean Society.
Keywords:
parasitoid, speciation, host range, behavioural
manipulation
Abstract:
Parasitoid wasps of the Polysphincta genus group are
usually highly specialised on their spider hosts and most of them are
known to manipulate their hosts into building a special web in which the
parasitoid pupates. The trophic niche and plasticity of host use
including host manipulations was investigated in the koinobiont
parasitoid Zatypota kauros Gauld from Queensland, Australia. We found
the parasitoid wasp to be unusual among spider parasitoids in attacking
hosts from three different families, each differing widely in their
web-building behaviours. Molecular analysis revealed that the taxon Z.
kauros contains at least two divergent mitochondrial lineages. Lineage A
was associated exclusively with spiders of the genus Anelosimus
(Theridiidae) and did not induce any changes in the structure of its
hostâ€™s tangle webs. Lineage B has a broader host range, including
spiders of the families Araneidae and Nephilidae, all of which weave
either orb or tent webs, but was also found on Anelosimus hosts. Unique
manipulations could be observed in the web-building behaviours of the
different host groups. However, nuclear data from two ribosomal genes
and three introns did not support the mitochondrial lineages or host
groups, indicating either maternal effects or very recent and/or
incomplete speciation in this taxon. Albeit, given their wide host range
and intriguing interactions with their hosts, the Z. kauros complex
represents a very promising system to study parasitoid speciation.
